STATUS 1 ON DUTY
STATUS 2 OFF DUTY
STATUS 3 INACTIVE - Fueling, Repairing, etc.
Example of going on duty and responding to a call; Brenkly, Status 1, going 10-1 loud to the previous call in R1.

ROUTINE CALL:
1. Make sure the scene is safe for you and the patient.
2. Check patient’s ABCs: - A = Airways - B = Breathing - C = Circulation
3. Check patient’s AVPU. - A = Alert and Conscious - V = Verbal - P = Responsive to Pain. - U = Unconscious.
4. Survey. - Patients: Sex, age, approx. weight. - Main problem. - Participating factors. - Allergies
5. Apply appropriate protocol
6. Transport.

PROTOCOLS: A
1. Abdominal Trauma.
a) Check ABCs b) Manage the blood loss c) Give oxygen d) Set an IV of Ringers Lactate e) Transport
2. Alcohol Emergency.
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) If pupils constricted give 1-2 mg of Naloxone. d) If patient is vomiting give 5-10mg of Compazine. e) Transport.
3. Altered Mental Status.
a) Check ABCs if possible. b) Give oxygen. c) If psychotic give 1-5mg of Haldol (Vitamin H) d) Transport
4. Anaphylaxis.
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) Give epinephrine 0.3mg
5. Asthma
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) If hypo-ventilating use BVM. d) If wheezing give 0.5ml of Albuterol via NRB. e) Consider use of 0.3mg of Epinephrine.

PROTOCOLS: B
1. Burns
a) Extinguish any flames b) Remove from harmful environment c) Check ABCs d) Flush the burns with cold water or saline. e) Give oxygen d) Set an IV with Ringer’s. e) Consider 3-5mg of Morphine. f) Transport
PROTOCOLS: C
1. Chest Pain
a) Check ABC b) Give oxygen c) Administer one nitroglycerine tablet sublingually d) Give 325mg (one tablet) of Aspirin orally. e) Consider 2mg of Morphine f) Transport
2. Chest Trauma.
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) If sucking chest wound (pneumothorax) Place occlusive dressing. d) Set IV e) If unconscious intubate, ventilating with BVM. f) If tension pneumothorax perform needle decompression of the chest. g) Impaled objects should be left in place. h) Transport
3. CVA (Cerebrovascular accident)/ Stroke
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) Set IV d) Elevate head if possible e) if sizing give 5-10mg of Valium f) Transport

PROCEDURES: D
1. Diabetic Emergency
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) Draw blood and check sugar levels. d) If hypoglycemia give 1mg of Glucagon. e) If hyperglycemia set the IV and give 10-25 units of insulin via the IV.
2. Dysrhythmias – Asystole
a) Check ABCs b) Initiate CPR c) Intubate d) Set IV e) Give 1mg of Epinephrine via IV. f) Administer 1mg of Atropine via IV. g) Transport
2. Dysrhythmias – Bradycardia
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) Set IV d) Give 4mg of Atropine via IV. e) Transport
3. Dysrhythmias – Tachycardia
a) Check ABCs b) Give oxygen c) Set IV d) Administer 1-1.5mg of Lidocaine via IV. e) Consider 2microgram/kg/min of Dopamine via IV.
4. Dysrhythmias – Ventricular Fibrillation
a) Check ABCs b) Perform CPR till defibrillator is prepared. c) Defibrillate 3 times at: 200, 300 and 360 Joules. d) If no effect Intubate d) Set an IV e) Administer 1mg of Epinephrine f) If patient is stabile transport, or transport during the procedures.

PROCEDURES: E
1. Eye injury.
a) Check ABCs b) instill 2 drops of Tetracaine ophtalmic drops. c) If chemical injury flush with normal saline all the time. d) Get the name of the chemical. e) Transport.
PROCEDURES: F
1. Fracture.
a) Check ABCs b) Consider 2-4mg of Morphine IM (intramuscularly) c) Immobilize fracture d) Transport

MEDICATIONS:
A
Aspirin - Platelet inhibitor/anti-inflammatory Dose: 150-325 Chewed.
Atropine - Increases heart rate Dose: Bradycardia: 0.5 mg every 5 minutes to maximum of 0.04 mg/kg. Asystole: 1 mg. Via IV.
Activated Charcoal – Absorbes toxins in gastric tract. Dose: 50-75g mixed with water to form a slurry.
D
Dextrose – Elevates sugar levels Dosage: 25mg
Diazepam (Valium) – Tranquilizer Dosage: 2-5mg IM or IV.
Dopamine – Increases the heart rate. Dosage: 800 mg should be placed in 500 ml of D5W IV only.
E
Epinephrine – Increases heart rate, blood pressure and dilates the bronchi’s. Dosage: 0.3-0.4mg subcutaneous or IV For cardiac arrest 0.5-1mg via IV.
H
Haldol (Vitamin H) – Major Tranquilizer used for Psychosis Dosage: 2-5mg IM
I
Insuline – Hormone Dosage: 15-25 units via IV.
L
Lasix – Lowers the Blood Pressure. Dosage: 40-80mg.
M
Morphine – Analgesic Dosage: 2-5mg
N
Naloxone – Narcotic Antagonist Dosage: 1-2mg

GLOSSARY
ABC- Airways, Breathing, Circulation
Anaphylactic Shock – Extreme allergic reaction that involves difficulty breathing and/or heart failure.
Arrhythmia – When the heart does not beat in its normal rhythm.
Asystole – A condition where the heart stops to beat.
Blood Pressure – Measure how good the blood circulates in the body. Normal BP is around 120/80
Bradycardia – State where the heart beat goes below 50 beats per minute.
BVM – Squeezable bag attached to a mask. Used in regulation of patients breath rate.
C-spine – Cervical, neck part of the spine.
CPR – Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation.
D5W – 5% glucose in saline solution.
Diastolic – Blood Pressure when the heart relaxes.
DOA – Dead On Arrival.
ECG – Electrocardiogram, measures heart activity.
GSW – Gun Shot Wound
Hyperglycemia – High levels of glucose in blood.
Hypoglycemia – Low levels of glucose in blood.
Hypovolemia – Sudden decrees of blood volume in the body. (Bleeding out)
IM – Intramuscular. (Into the muscle)
IV – Intravenous (Into Vein)
OD – Overdose
Tachycardia – High pulse over 100 beats per minute.
Vitamin H – Haldol
